slides.title: Measures of Central Tendency
slides.content:
**Central Tendency:**
Measures that represent the center of data.

**1. Mean (Arithmetic Average):**

**For ungrouped data:**
**Mean = (x₁ + x₂ + ... + xₙ)/n = Σx/n**

**Example:**
Data: 2, 4, 6, 8, 10
Mean = (2+4+6+8+10)/5 = 30/5 = 6

**For grouped data:**
**Mean = Σ(f·x)/Σf**

where f = frequency, x = class mark

**2. Median:**
Middle value when data is arranged in order.

**For odd n:** Median = ((n+1)/2)th term
**For even n:** Median = average of (n/2)th and (n/2+1)th terms

**Example:**
Data: 3, 7, 2, 9, 5 → Arranged: 2, 3, 5, 7, 9
n = 5 (odd)
Median = 3rd term = 5

**3. Mode:**
Most frequently occurring value.

**Example:**
Data: 2, 3, 3, 4, 5, 3, 6
Mode = 3 (appears 3 times)

**Relation:**
For moderately skewed distribution:
**Mode = 3(Median) - 2(Mean)**

slides.title: Measures of Dispersion
slides.content:
**Dispersion:**
Measures of spread or variation in data.

**1. Range:**
**Range = Maximum - Minimum**

**Example:**
Data: 2, 5, 8, 12, 15
Range = 15 - 2 = 13

**2. Mean Deviation:**
**MD = Σ|x - Mean|/n**

**3. Variance:**
Average of squared deviations from mean.

**σ² = Σ(x - x̄)²/n**

Or: **σ² = (Σx²/n) - (Σx/n)²**

**Example:**
Data: 2, 4, 6, 8, 10
Mean = 6

Variance = [(2-6)² + (4-6)² + (6-6)² + (8-6)² + (10-6)²]/5
= [16 + 4 + 0 + 4 + 16]/5
= 40/5 = 8

**4. Standard Deviation:**
**σ = √Variance = √[Σ(x-x̄)²/n]**

For above example:
σ = √8 = 2√2

**Coefficient of Variation:**
**CV = (σ/x̄) × 100%**

Used to compare variability of different datasets.

**Properties:**
- If each value increases by k: new mean = old mean + k, σ unchanged
- If each value multiplied by k: new mean = k × old mean, new σ = k × old σ

slides.title: Probability - Basics
slides.content:
**Probability:**
Measure of likelihood of an event.

**Sample Space (S):**
Set of all possible outcomes.

**Event (E):**
Subset of sample space.

**Example:**
Experiment: Tossing a coin
Sample space: S = {H, T}
Event E = getting head = {H}

**Classical Definition:**
**P(E) = n(E)/n(S)**

where n(E) = favorable outcomes
      n(S) = total outcomes

**Example:**
Probability of getting 3 on die:
S = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}, n(S) = 6
E = {3}, n(E) = 1
P(E) = 1/6

**Range of Probability:**
**0 ≤ P(E) ≤ 1**

- P(certain event) = 1
- P(impossible event) = 0
- P(E) + P(not E) = 1

**Complementary Event:**
**P(E') = 1 - P(E)**

where E' = complement of E = not E

**Odds:**
- Odds in favor = P(E)/P(E')
- Odds against = P(E')/P(E)

slides.title: Probability Rules
slides.content:
**Addition Rule:**

**For mutually exclusive events:**
P(A or B) = P(A ∪ B) = P(A) + P(B)

**For any two events:**
**P(A ∪ B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A ∩ B)**

**Example:**
P(card is king or queen)
= P(king) + P(queen)
= 4/52 + 4/52 = 8/52 = 2/13

**Multiplication Rule:**

**For independent events:**
**P(A and B) = P(A ∩ B) = P(A) × P(B)**

**Example:**
P(head on coin AND 6 on die)
= (1/2) × (1/6) = 1/12

**For dependent events:**
**P(A ∩ B) = P(A) × P(B|A)**

where P(B|A) = probability of B given A

**Conditional Probability:**
**P(B|A) = P(A ∩ B)/P(A)**

**Example:**
Two cards drawn without replacement.
P(both kings) = P(1st king) × P(2nd king | 1st king)
= (4/52) × (3/51)
= 12/2652 = 1/221

**Independent Events:**
A and B are independent if:
**P(A ∩ B) = P(A) × P(B)**

Or: **P(B|A) = P(B)**

slides.title: Probability Distributions
slides.content:
**Random Variable:**
Variable whose value depends on random experiment.

**Types:**
- Discrete: Takes specific values (1, 2, 3, ...)
- Continuous: Takes any value in interval

**Probability Distribution:**
Table showing values and their probabilities.

**Properties:**
1. 0 ≤ P(X = x) ≤ 1 for all x
2. ΣP(X = x) = 1

**Example:**
X = number on die
P(X = 1) = P(X = 2) = ... = P(X = 6) = 1/6

**Expected Value (Mean):**
**E(X) = Σ[x · P(x)]**

**Example:**
X: 1, 2, 3
P(X): 1/2, 1/3, 1/6

E(X) = 1(1/2) + 2(1/3) + 3(1/6)
= 1/2 + 2/3 + 1/2
= 1 + 2/3 = 5/3

**Variance:**
**Var(X) = E(X²) - [E(X)]²**

**Binomial Distribution:**
For n independent trials, each with probability p:

**P(X = r) = ⁿCᵣ pʳ qⁿ⁻ʳ**

where q = 1 - p

**Mean:** np
**Variance:** npq

**Example:**
Coin tossed 3 times, P(2 heads):
n = 3, r = 2, p = 1/2, q = 1/2

P(X = 2) = ³C₂(1/2)²(1/2)¹
= 3 × 1/4 × 1/2 = 3/8

slides.title: Permutation and Probability
slides.content:
**Using Permutations in Probability:**

**Example 1: Arrangement Problems**
Probability that letters of INDIA can be arranged with vowels together:

Total arrangements = 5!/2! (I repeats)
= 60

Favorable: Treat II as one unit
= 4! = 24

P = 24/60 = 2/5

**Example 2: Selection Problems**
P(selecting 2 red balls from 5 red and 3 blue):

Total ways to select 2 from 8: ⁸C₂ = 28
Favorable ways: ⁵C₂ = 10

P = 10/28 = 5/14

**Cards Probability:**
Standard deck: 52 cards
- 4 suits (hearts, diamonds, clubs, spades)
- Each suit: 13 cards (A, 2-10, J, Q, K)
- Face cards: J, Q, K (12 total)
- Red cards: 26, Black cards: 26

**Dice Probability:**
One die: 6 outcomes
Two dice: 36 outcomes

**Common Results:**
- P(sum = 7 on two dice) = 6/36 = 1/6
- P(doublet) = 6/36 = 1/6
- P(sum ≥ 10) = 6/36 = 1/6

slides.title: Exam Strategy for Statistics & Probability
slides.content:
**Topic Distribution:**
- Mean, median, mode: 2-3 questions
- Variance & standard deviation: 2-3 questions
- Basic probability: 3-4 questions
- Conditional probability: 2-3 questions
- Cards/dice problems: 2-3 questions
- Binomial distribution: 1-2 questions

**Must Memorize:**

**Statistics:**
- Mean: Σx/n (ungrouped), Σfx/Σf (grouped)
- Variance: Σ(x-x̄)²/n or Σx²/n - (Σx/n)²
- SD: σ = √Variance
- Mode = 3(Median) - 2(Mean)

**Probability:**
- P(E) = n(E)/n(S)
- P(E') = 1 - P(E)
- P(A ∪ B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A ∩ B)
- P(A ∩ B) = P(A) × P(B) (independent)
- P(B|A) = P(A ∩ B)/P(A)

**Binomial:**
- P(X = r) = ⁿCᵣ pʳ qⁿ⁻ʳ
- Mean = np, Variance = npq

**Card Facts:**
- Total cards: 52
- Suits: 4 (each 13 cards)
- Face cards: 12
- Aces: 4
- Red/Black: 26 each

**Time Allocation:**
- Mean/median: 30-60 sec
- Variance/SD: 90-120 sec
- Basic probability: 45-60 sec
- Conditional probability: 90-120 sec
- Binomial: 120-180 sec

**Common Mistakes:**
❌ Confusing P(A ∪ B) with P(A ∩ B)
❌ Forgetting to subtract P(A ∩ B) in addition rule
❌ Using P(A) × P(B) for dependent events
❌ Not arranging data for median

**Quick Tips:**
- Always check if events are independent
- For cards: remember total = 52
- Variance = E(X²) - [E(X)]²
- Practice conditional probability thoroughly
